title: 1770 Bonne Map of Northern India, Burma and Pakistan
description: A beautiful example of Rigobert Bonne's 1770 decorative map of northern India. Covers the subcontinent from Kandahar east as far as Burma (Pegu) and south to just past Goa. Names countless important Indian cities, river systems and mines. Rhumb lines appear in nautical zones. Arrows in the lower left and lower right show the direction of prevailing winds during the dry season and the monsoon season. Drawn by R. Bonne in 1770 for issue as plate no. A 26 in Jean Lattre's 1776 issue of the Atlas Moderne .
creator: Rigobert Bonne
subject: Map
source: Lattre, Jean, Atlas Moderne ou Collection de Cartes sur Toutes les Parties du Globe Terrestre, c. 1775.
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: 1776 Rennell - Dury Wall Map of Bihar and Bengal, India
description: An altogether spectacular wall sized map of those parts of Bengal and Bihar, India. Follows the course of the Ganges River from Varanasi (Benares) eastward to the Ganges Delta and the Bay of Bengal. Includes Varanasi (Benares), Dacca (Dahka, Bengladesh), and Patna among many other important Indian cities. Bounded on the north by the Himalaya Mountains and the border with Bhutan. One of the first accurate maps of the interior of India. Laid out from primary surveys done by James Rennell, the first modern cartographer to map the interior of India. Notes cities, markets, battlefields, fortresses, roads, rivers, offers political commentary, and features some geographical references. Elaborate title in the lower left quadrant. Upper right quadrant features a dedication and letter of thanks written by Andrew Dury, the publisher, to the board of the East India Company. This is the first edition of this rare map – 1776 – as published by Dury. Later editions were published by Sayer and Bennet and by Laurie and Whittle.
creator: Major James Rennell
subject: Map
source: The Bengal Atlas, Rennell, James, (1779 first edition)
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Scarcity in India
description: This is one of a pair of Singleton prints that contrast British wealth with food shortages in India during 1769-1770. Two sailors are bargaining with a scantily clad Indian girl with a basket of fruit. Although pineapples were luxury goods at this time, the mirror, and in particular the watch offered by the seaman on the left represent a disproportionately high price for the fruit. The girl’s hairstyle resembles a pineapple reinforcing the point that she is the object of their attention rather than her wares.
creator: Henry Singleton, Charles Knight
subject: Painting
source: National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, London, Caird Collection
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Hasan Riza Khan Bahadur
description: Naib Nazim of Dhaka Hasan Riza khan Bahadur is collecting Divan from zamindars. He informed Harry Verelst, President of the Council at Fort William about the "dryness of the season". On 7 December, Reza Khan and Shitab Rai proposed to the Council that they enforce a humane grain collection scheme for the upcoming fiscal year, in proportion to the individual produce of peasants. Acting upon the advice of Reza Khan, the Council chose to increase taxes by 10% to meet revenue targets.

title: Drawing Disaster: Prologue
description: In 1764, the East India Company (EIC) became the new revenue collector of the Bengal province by acquiring Dewani rights, and completing their already vice-like grip on the administration of the region. The Nawabs (any Muslim ruler in North or South India) and Kings became 'puppets', controlled by the EIC. This uprooted previously well-established traditions, and, as inferred here, had a great impact on the severity of the famine of 1769/70.
creator: Argha Manna, Debkumar Mitra
subject: Graphic Narrative
source: Famine Tale: From India and Britain

title: Famine Sketches for Bengal Districts
description: In the graphic art story, the character Debdulal Mitra shows William Wilson Hunter an old sketchbook given to him by his guru, which is filled with intricate and shocking sketches from famines past, with particular reference to Chhiattor-er Monnotor. This extraordinary fictitious touch allows the historical moment of the 1770 famine to come alive in its own way.

title: Environmental History: Effects of Floods and Droughts

title: Map of Birbhum

title: John Cartier
description: John Cartier was a British colonial governor in India from 1769 to 1772. On 25 January 1770, Cartier proposed to the Board that land taxes be remitted by about seven percent in afflicted areas on grounds of widespread suffering. He was blamed for ignoring warnings about the impending disaster. In response to the crisis, the Court of Directors sent a three-person commission to Bengal to assess the situation. However, the ship carrying the three members foundered at sea. The Court of Directors did not send a replacement and recalled Cartier. Warren Hastings was selected as his replacement; he took office on 28 April 1772.
creator: UNKNOWN
subject: Governor of Bengal; ; East India Company
source: IndiaNetzone, Wikipedia
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Memorial to Harry Verelst
description: Harry Verelst became the Governor of Bengal from 1767 to 1769 after Robert Clive quit the position. On 18 September 1769, Naib Nazim of Dhaka Mohammed Reza Khan informed Harry Verelst, President of the Council at Fort William about the "dryness of the season". A century later, W. W. Hunter would note that John Cartier's letter to be the "only serious intimation" about the approaching famine, and find the absence of President Verelst's affirmation to be striking.
creator: Tedster007
subject: President of the Council at Fort William; East India Company
source: Wikipedia
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: John Shore
description: John Shore, 1st Baron Teignmouth, 1st Baronet (5 October 1751 – 14 February 1834) was a British official of the East India Company who served as Governor-General of Bengal from 1793 to 1798. Soon after his arrival in Calcutta, in May 1769 Shore was appointed to the secret political department, in which he remained for about twelve months. In September 1770 he was nominated assistant to the board of revenue at Murshidabad.
creator: George Richmond
subject: Painting; Watercolor
source: Wikimedia Commons
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Warren Hastings
description: Warren Hastings FRS (6 December 1732 – 22 August 1818) was a British colonial administrator, who served as the first Governor of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal), the head of the Supreme Council of Bengal, and so the first Governor-General of Bengal in 1772–1785. He created an efficient postal service, backed a proper cartographical survey of India by James Rennell and built a series of public granaries, including the great Gola at Patna, to make sure the famine of 1770-71 was never repeated.
creator: Kathleen Blechynden
subject: Painting
source: Wikimedia Commons
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Bhagalpur
description: Bhagalpur, historically known as Champa Nagri, is a city in the Indian state of Bihar, situated on the southern bank of the Ganges river. Mr. William  Harwood, Supervisor of Rajmahal and Bhagalpur, wrote on 23rd April, 1770, “ As a proof of this (severity of famine) I need only mention the number of souls who have perished thro’ want to Boglepoor town, within the last five months (i.e. from December 1769 to April 1770), which upon a strict enquiry I find to exceed one-third of the inhabitants.”

title: Rajshahi
description: Before the outbreak,there were 265 families in the 11 villages of the Maner parganah. Out of 265 families, only 127 families survived at the end of 1771. There was areduction of 51 ½  % of the families. In the fifteen villages of the Arwal parganah there were 291 families before the famine, but at the end of the year 1771 only 157 families survived.ed. Thus there was a reduction of about 46 per cent of the families in fifteen villages of the Arwal Parganah.
